entry.title: Test Data Conversion, the accelerator: scaling smart
entry.content:
In our Data Migration for Test Environment Validation in ... - SAP Community Blog, we explored Test Data Conversion (TDC) and Test Data Refresh (TDR), the potential pathways for test system readiness as part of the 3 SL post-conversion activity. We have also seen the unique value added by both the services. If you're seeking deeper insight into Test Data Conversion (TDC), you're in the right place. In this blog we will see a comprehensive overview of TDC, purpose, and value added by TDC.  

Customer satisfaction is the cornerstone of any business. To ensure a seamless transition into 3 SL conversion, TDC is being offered as a one-time complimentary service to all the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 3 SL conversion customers by SAP. 

Before we delve into the full scope and benefits of TDC, Let‚Äôs have an understanding on the key prerequisites for TDC implementation. 

TDC Pre-requisites: 

To ensure a seamless and efficient data transfer during the TDC enablement process, below key prerequisites must be fulfilled at the system level: 

  1. Uniform Software Release Across all tenants: 
    • All Tenants must operate on the same software release configuration. 
    • This consistency helps eliminate system discrepancies and ensures reliable data flow. 
  2. System Configuration Maintenance 
    • A well-maintained System configuration is essential for seamless TDC execution. 
    • It supports system stability there by reduces integration friction.  
  3. Content Version Alignment 
    • All tenants should be in the same content version release. 
    • Version mismatches can lead to errors during data transfer and could lead to incomplete data mapping.  
  4. Extension Readiness 
    • Ensure all relevant extensions are active and configured with the latest updates. 
    • The Handle Your Extensions app will come handy to verify and manage extensions efficiently. 
  5. Clean Development Transport Queue 
    • Confirm that there are no open transports in the development queue. 
    • The transport queue should be clean to avoid data inconsistency or conflicts. 

Note:  if you need help with the first three prerequisites, The conversion team will help you to validate and maintain the necessary configurations across tenants. This simplifies the process and ensures readiness for TDC onboarding. 

TDC: Enabling Seamless Data Transition for tenant post-conversion 

The TDC service offers a powerful solution for transferring reliable data from the development tenant to the test tenant. It supports the migration of: 

  • Master Data 
  • Transactional Data 
  • Historical Test Data 
  • System Configurations (e.g., Output Management and others) 

 By this, TDC will not only take care of data, but also help in setting up certain configurations thereby reduces manual setup efforts and accelerate system readiness process. One of the critical components in system setup is the Output Management Configuration. TDC streamlines this process by automatically transferring output management configuration data from the development tenant to the new test tenant. In addition to configuration data, TDC also migrates all available test automation assets, ensuring that testing frameworks and scripts are ready to resume at the earliest. 

One of the key concerns during data migration is data privacy. TDC service offers depersonalization as an optional feature, which ensures sensitive information (Workforce data is out of scope) is anonymized during the transfer process. 

Note: Depersonalization is a broad and critical topic. While this blog focuses on understanding TDC, reference links will be provided below for those who wish to explore depersonalization in detail. 

Once the data migration via TDC is complete, the system reaches a near-ready state, as a next step initiate Rewiring of Applications as a Post migration step to ensure the alignment of applications with the new test tenant. This step ensures seamless integration with applications and functionality across the system landscape. 

Note: Rewiring of apps is beyond the scope of this blog. Kindly refer to SAP help page for those who wish to explore Rewiring of apps in more detail. 

With consistent and complete data in place and successful rewiring of apps, the test tenant becomes fully operational. This marks the transition of test tenant from setup to active usage. All available test automation scripts from the development tenant can now be resumed. This helps to validate system integrity, confirm readiness, and ensure smooth performance post conversion. 

Conclusion: 

In this Blog, we‚Äôve explored the pre-requisite, scope of TDC. We've also seen how TDC significantly reducing manual effort and saving time during the 3 SL post conversion process. 

We hope this has provided you with a comprehensive and clear understanding of TDC, its benefits, and its role in enabling a smoother transition to the new Test tenant. 

 Reference: 

  • Data Migration for Test Environment Validation in ... - SAP Community
  • 3SL Conversion for two-system landscape customers managed by SAP Central Business Configuration
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud 3SL onboarding and initial system set-up series
  • Streamlining 3SL Post Conversion Steps: Introducing CIAS and TDC Services
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/test-data-refresh-service-request-on-sap-f...

For more details about the‚ÄØHandle Your Extensions‚ÄØapp and its use, refer to the‚ÄØBlog - Handle Your Extensions - test data refresh.‚ÄØ

entry.title: Enabling Agent Interoperability: A Practical Path from API to MCP Server
entry.content:
The future of enterprise AI will be driven by the deep and seamless integration of LLMs into existing enterprise products and workflows. To stay competitive, companies must make their vast landscape of existing capabilities directly accessible and usable by AI, empowering a new generation of intelligent ecosystems. This requires a clear strategy for enabling agent interoperability.

In this article, we will establish that the journey to agent interoperability begins with a foundational pillar: enabling agents to reliably connect with tools (Agent-to-Tool). We'll start by defining the foundational challenge that prevents agents and tools from communicating effectively. We will then introduce the Model Context Protocol (MCP) as a standardized solution and walk through a step-by-step tutorial on how to transform a standard REST API into a fully compliant MCP Server using a cloud-native gateway.

 

What is Agent Interoperability and Why Does It Matter?

Agent Interoperability is a comprehensive framework for a complete AI ecosystem, which relies on two fundamental pillars: Agent-to-Agent (A2A) interaction and Agent-to-Tool (A2T) interaction.

While A2A interaction‚Äîhow agents collaborate and delegate tasks‚Äîrepresents a sophisticated, multi-agent system's goal, A2T interaction is the foundational prerequisite. The ability of agents to collaborate is contingent upon their individual capacity to connect to tools.

Therefore, solving the Agent-to-Tool challenge is the most critical first step towards the broader goal of agent interoperability. While not an Agent-to-Agent protocol itself, solving the Agent-to-Tool challenge is the most critical first step towards the broader goal of agent interoperability: how to let any agent discover and use any external capability in a standardized way.

 

Foundational Challenge: Connecting Agents to Enterprise Tools

In an enterprise environment like SAP, this challenge presents distinct engineering considerations on both sides of the connection:

  • On the agent side: The challenge is building agents with the autonomy to dynamically discover and utilize a diverse set of capabilities, moving beyond static tool integrations.
  • On the capability side: The engineering task is to adapt SAP's vast landscape of powerful APIs for a new type of consumer: the autonomous AI agent. The goal is to create AI-consumable interfaces for these existing capabilities, which involves adding the necessary semantic context and standardized formats that agents require for dynamic interaction.

This difference in design paradigms creates a natural "Interoperability Gap‚Äù. Bridging this gap requires a foundational layer for communication: a standardized protocol that enables dynamic discovery and standardized interaction between agents and established enterprise APIs.

 

The Solution: MCP as a Standardized Protocol Bridge

So, how do we bridge this "Interoperability Gap"? The solution lies in a shared standard‚Äîa common language that both agents and tools can speak. This is where the Model Context Protocol (MCP)  comes in.

MCP is an open protocol that standardizes how applications provide context to large language models (LLMs). MCP provides a standardized way to connect AI models to different data sources and tools.

We use MCP to build agents and complex workflows on top of LLMs. The key participants in the MCP architecture are:

  • MCP Host: The AI application that coordinates and manages one or multiple MCP clients
  • MCP Client: A component that maintains a connection to an MCP server and obtains context from an MCP server for the MCP host to use
  • MCP Server: A program that provides context to MCP clients

As for enterprise like SAP, the best practice will be:

However, a protocol is only useful if capabilities adopt it. The enterprise landscape is filled with valuable, pre-existing REST APIs that were not built for this new paradigm. Therefore, a critical first step toward achieving agent interoperability is to bridge these legacy APIs to the MCP standard.

The act of transforming a standard API into a discoverable MCP Server is the foundational process for unlocking existing enterprise value for AI agents. 

 

MCP Adoption Strategy in Enterprise Ecosystems

When adopting a new standard like MCP within a large enterprise ecosystem like SAP, there are typically two primary strategic paths to consider for implementation:

1. The Standard Path: Platform-Managed Solutions

For most common use cases, the standard approach is to leverage platform-integrated, centrally managed solutions. This path involves using automated services, often provided by the enterprise platform (e.g., SAP BTP), to convert existing APIs into standardized tools. By using unified method for transformation, this approach ensures consistency and manageability across the entire ecosystem.

2. The Flexible Path: Custom or "Native" Implementations

For scenario demanding greater flexibility or more complex business logic, a more custom approach is required. This involves building what can be considered "native" MCP servers. This approach allows teams to build custom implementations using a variety of technologies, such as open-source libraries or different programming languages, giving them full control over the implementation.

This Guide's Focus: A Hands-on Example of the Flexible Path

In the following guide, we will focus on the flexible, native server approach.  We will demonstrate a powerful and practical pattern for this by using a cloud-native gateway, Higress, to wrap an existing API. This method is ideal for teams who require full control over the transformation logic and deployment environment, providing a valuable, hands-on example of building a native-style MCP server.

 

Step-by-Step Guide: Transforming API into MCP Server

To see how this concept works in the real world, let's take a standard REST API and use a gateway to transform it into a fully-compliant MCP server.

Our Goal: Wrap a simple HTTP API as an MCP Server and invoke it from an agent.

Our Tools:

  • A Simple API: A REST API that returns real-time currency exchange data.
  • The Gateway: Higress, an open-source, cloud-native gateway with a powerful plugin architecture.
  • The Standard: The Model Context Protocol (MCP), which we'll implement using the Higress MCP Plugin.
  • The Environment: A Kubernetes environment.

 

A Modern Transport Protocol: Streamable HTTP

Before we begin, it's important to understand transport mechanisms for client-server communication we'll be using. This guide utilizes a modern and powerful approach defined by the MCP standard: Streamable HTTP.

We chose this approach for several key advantages that make it superior for modern AI systems:

  • Simplified Architecture: In the Streamable HTTP transport, the server operates as an independent process that can handle multiple client connections. Because the session context is maintained within this single, stateful connection, the need for an external session manager like Redis is often eliminated.
  • Bidirectional and Flexible Communication: The protocol handles simple request-response patterns efficiently but also enables true bidirectional communication. Server can optionally make use of Server-Sent Events (SSE) to stream multiple server messages. This permits basic MCP servers, as well as more feature-rich servers supporting streaming and server-to-client notifications and requests.

 

Step 1: The Starting Point - A Simple REST API

As the requirement of Streamable HTTP, The server MUST provide a single HTTP endpoint path (hereafter referred to as the MCP endpoint) that supports both POST and GET methods.

To demonstrate the transformation process, this guide will use the ExchangeRate-API, a professional service that provides real-time currency exchange data. We'll use its lasted endpoint, which returns up-to-date global rates based on the US Dollar.

  • API Endpoint: https://open.er-api.com/v6/latest/USD

A successful request to this endpoint returns a JSON object with a structure similar to this, containing metadata and a nested rates object:

{
  "result": "success",
  "time_last_update_utc": "Mon, 15 Sep 2025 00:02:31 +0000",
  "base_code": "USD",
  "rates": {
    "USD": 1,
    "EUR": 0.925,
    "GBP": 0.789,
    ...
  }
}

This represents a typical "legacy" capability‚Äîuseful, but not inherently agent-friendly. 

 

Step 2: Preparing the Gateway with Higress

Instead of modifying the API's code, we'll use a gateway to act as a transformation layer. Higress is an ideal choice because its plugin architecture is designed to extend gateway capabilities, including native support for AI scenarios through protocols like MCP.

2.1 Higress Deployment

First, install Higress into your cluster environment (To simplify, we use k3s as an example).

Check your console's node port:

kubectl get svc higress-console -n higress-system

Once the installation succeeds, you can access the Higress Console in browser by http://<your-cluster-external-ip>:<console-port>.  

 

2.2 Config MCP Server

Once deployed, we need to enable the MCP Server functionality globally by editing the higress-config ConfigMap.

kubectl edit configmap higress-config -n higress-system

In the ConfigMap data, we'll add the MCP Server configuration. 

apiVersion: v1
data:
  higress: |-
    mcpServer:
      sse_path_suffix: /sse  # Suffix for the Server-Sent Events connection path
      enable: true           # Enable the MCP Server
      servers: []
  downstream:
    # ... (rest of the config)

 

Step 3: Transforming the API with the MCP Plugin

3.1 Add a Service Source

In the Higress Console, navigate to Service Source page http://<your-cluster-external-ip>:<console-port>/service-source  and add a new source pointing to our API's address (https://open.er-api.com/v6/latest/USD).

 

3.2 Create a Route

Next, go to the Route page and create a new route.

  • Click "Route Config" on the left sidebar
  • Click "Create Route" button
  • Fill in the form with the following details:
    • Route Name: exchange-rate-route
    • Path: Select Exact and enter /exchange-rates
    • Target Service: Select the service source you just created

This will create a route that matches the path /exchange-rates and forwards requests to the service source you created. Now you can see the new route in the list.

At this point, Higress will simply proxy requests from /exchange-rates to our API.

 

3. Configure the MCP Server Plugin

Click the Strategy link on your new route and find the MCP Server plugin.

 

After enabling the plugin, click "Configure" and switch to the YAML view. This is where we define the metadata that makes our API discoverable and understandable to agents.

 

Paste the following configuration:

server:
  name: "exchange-rate-server"
tools:
  - name: "get-latest-usd-rates"
    description: "Fetches the latest currency exchange rates based on the US Dollar."
    requestTemplate:
      method: "GET"
      url: "https://open.er-api.com/v6/latest/USD"
    responseTemplate:
      body: |-
        **Latest Exchange Rates (Base: {{.base_code}})**
        *Updated at: {{.time_last_update_utc}}*
        
        - **Euro (EUR):** {{.rates.EUR}}
        - **Japanese Yen (JPY):** {{.rates.JPY}}
        - **British Pound (GBP):** {{.rates.GBP}}
        - **Chinese Yuan (CNY):** {{.rates.CNY}}

Let's break this down:

  • server.name: A human-readable name for our new MCP server.
  • tools: A list of capabilities this server provides.
  • name & description: The crucial metadata for agent to intelligently discover and select this tool when a user asks about exchange rates.
  • requestTemplate & responseTemplate: These define how Higress calls the backend API and formats the response. Here, the requestTemplate specifies a simple GET request, and the responseTemplate transforms the JSON output into a clean, agent-friendly format.

Save the plugin configuration. Our standard REST API is now exposed as a fully functional and discoverable MCP Server, ready for any compliant AI agent to use.

 

Step 4: Connecting and Invoking from an Agent with Streamable HTTP

Now, any MCP-compliant agent or client can connect to our gateway and use this new tool. To test our new MCP server, we can use any compliant MCP Host app, such as Cline, Cursor, Trae, etc.

For this guide, we'll use Cline as example. It's an autonomous coding agent that can be installed as a VS Code extension. Configure Cline with the following setting to establish a connection to our new server:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "exchange-rate-server": {
      "url": "http://<your-cluster-external-ip>/exchange-rates",
      "type": "streamableHttp"
    }
  }
}

Now you can test the server in Cline:

 

Wrapping Up

In this post, we've navigated a practical path toward the broader vision of agent interoperability. We established that the most critical first step is solving the Agent-to-Tool (A2T) challenge: making existing enterprise APIs discoverable and usable by AI agents. We then demonstrated a powerful pattern to achieve this, using a cloud-native gateway, Higress, to transform a standard REST API into a fully compliant MCP Server.

The most powerful takeaway is demonstrating a flexible path to a native server: You've learned how a gateway-centric pattern can be used to build a "native" MCP server, offering full control to teams that require flexibility and customization in their MCP adoption strategy. It means existing, valuable enterprise services can be rapidly integrated into the agent ecosystem, making them dynamically discoverable and usable by any MCP-compliant agent.

Solving the Agent-to-Tool problem building the foundation for agent interoperability. With a robust A2T layer in place, the path is cleared for more advanced Agent-to-Agent collaboration, paves the way for a future where countless enterprise services can be seamlessly integrated with agent ecosystem.

entry.title: Re: How to create record Technical Object in Change Sales...
entry.content:
Hi Phuhs,

You can set up automatic serial number creation for sales orders in the serial number profile customizing. You have to set procedure SDAU (Serial numbers in SD order) to 04 (Automatic) for your serial number profile.

If you want to influence the automatic numbering via BAdI, you can use BAdI LOSN_SER_NUM_INT_CREATE for developer extensibility (Eclipse ADT) or LOSN_CBO_SERIAL_NUMBER_INT for key user extensibility (Custom Logic app).
The corresponding help document: 
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/20f4d8b2420544f7a5e41471c5bf5dac.html

BR,
Alex

entry.title: Re: smart filter bar not visible after smart table person...
entry.content:
Hi @Anjan_3331 ,

A few things you might try to see if they help with the Smart Filter Bar disappearing when a custom default variant is used:

  1. Bind to SmartVariantManagement

    • Try wrapping the SmartFilterBar with a SmartVariantManagement and give both controls stable persistencyKey values. This may ensure the default variant (and visibility) persists across sessions.

  2. Try to Recreate the default variant with ‚ÄúShow Filter Bar‚Äù on

    • When saving the variant, ensure the filter bar isn‚Äôt hidden. Sometimes a hidden flag gets persisted and might be the bar won‚Äôt show after re-login cause of a wrongly saved variant.

  3. Reset personalization and retest

    • In FLP, reset user settings/personalization and rebuild the variant to rule out stale metadata.

  4. Minimal repro

    • Try the same in a fresh Fiori Elements template (SmartFilterBar + SmartVariantManagement) to see if the behavior reproduces. If it does, it‚Äôs likely config/persistence rather than app logic.

  5. Collect hints

    • After login, open DevTools and check console/network for variant‚Äêload messages or errors related to SmartVariantManagement.

If any of these help, you can narrow it down further; otherwise, sharing a small XML snippet of the filter bar/variant setup might help the community suggest next steps.

Regards,

Sudheer

entry.title: Re: Base quantity, fixed lot size not updating using BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA?
entry.content:
You have to choose cost_view in headdata, then it works!

    DATA:
      ls_headdata   TYPE bapimathead,
      ls_client     TYPE bapi_mara,
      ls_clientx    TYPE bapi_marax,
      ls_plantdata  TYPE bapi_marc,
      ls_plantdatax TYPE bapi_marcx,
      lt_return     TYPE TABLE OF bapiret2.


    "Headerinfos
    ls_headdata-material  = iv_matnr.
    ls_headdata-cost_view = 'X'. 

    "Plantdata
    ls_plantdata-plant    = iv_werks.
    ls_plantdata-lot_size = iv_losgr. 

    ls_plantdatax-plant    = iv_werks.
    ls_plantdatax-lot_size = 'X'. 

    CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA'
      EXPORTING
        headdata       = ls_headdata
        plantdata      = ls_plantdata
        plantdatax     = ls_plantdatax
      IMPORTING
        return         = rs_return
      TABLES
        returnmessages = et_return.

    IF rs_return-type CA 'EAX'.
      IF if_commit = abap_true.
        CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_TRANSACTION_ROLLBACK'.
      ENDIF.
    ELSE.
      IF if_commit = abap_true.
        CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT'
          EXPORTING
            wait = 'X'.
      ENDIF.
      CLEAR rs_return.
    ENDIF.

entry.title: GL Accounts Missing in Test and Production for New Company Code
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

we‚Äôre currently setting up a new company code XY. According to our configuration, this company code should have the same GL accounts assigned as company code XX.

However, we‚Äôve encountered a strange situation:

In Test, none of the GL accounts are available for company code XY.

In Production, only a few GL accounts appear ‚Äî most are missing.

Has anyone experienced something similar? What could cause such discrepancies between Test and Production, or between the two company codes? Any tips on how to troubleshoot or verify the configuration would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you in advance 

Images attached of customizing, test, prod.

entry.title: Re: data not archiving from BSAS, BSAK and BSAD
entry.content:
Hi,

It seems you didnt execute "PostProc" step in TCode SARA for the object FI_DOCUMNT

This step is responsible for deleting those tables contents (BSID, BSAD, BSAK, ...)

You will be asked to create a new variant for "PostProc" step (as it is a different program not the same as Write program). Use the same values you used for Write program variant.

entry.title: Re: ABAP RAP Functions - Managed Scenario not triggering
Re: How to setup authentication in External FIORI APP for...
entry.content:
Hi @G_Sachin ,

From what you describe it sounds like the app is still using a communication user directly, which is why you‚Äôre seeing the credentials popup. In SAP Public Cloud the usual way to avoid that popup is to switch from a technical user login to an end-user SSO / principal propagation type of setup.

I‚Äôd recommend working with your SAP BTP architect or Basis/Integration team to set up the trust and destination settings needed for your external Fiori app. With their help you can configure the app and its destination so that once the user is logged in to the Cloud Identity Service, the OData calls run automatically without another login prompt.

Hope this helps point you in the right direction.

entry.title: Setting up Open Payment Framework in SAP Commerce Cloud - Video Series Walkthrough
entry.content:
Are you looking to streamline your payment processes within SAP Commerce Cloud? Wondering how to seamlessly integrate payment gateways like Stripe and manage transactions efficiently? Let me introduce you a comprehensive playlist of step-by-step videos designed to guide you through the entire journey of integrating payment services using the SAP Commerce Cloud, Open Payment Framework (OPF).

This curated series covers everything from initial setup to advanced management techniques, ensuring you have all the tools and knowledge needed to build a reliable and secure payment ecosystem with the Open Payment Framework and SAP Commerce Cloud.

1. Start with Setting Up Your Payment Gateway

The journey begins with setting up your payment service provider account - in this case, Stripe (as an application example), a widely used and essential payment processing platform for integrating payments with SAP Commerce Cloud. The first video walks you through the account creation process:

Creating a Stripe Account for Open Payment Framework and SAP Commerce Cloud Integration

Once your Stripe account is ready, the next step is to connect it to SAP Commerce Cloud through the Open Payment Framework by creating a payment integration:

Creating a Payment Integration with Open Payment Framework Workbench

2. Configuring Payment Authorization & Testing

With the integration in place, you‚Äôll want to configure how payments are authorized within SAP Commerce Cloud. This involves initializing a payment form:

Configuring Payment Authorization By Initializing A Payment Form within Open Payment Framework

To ensure everything works smoothly, you'll learn how to test and troubleshoot the checkout page, verifying that the integration correctly processes transactions:

Testing and Troubleshooting the Checkout Page in Payment Integration with the Open Payment Framework

3. Setting Up Verification & Managing Payment References

Following the basic authorization setup, there's a critical step to set up payment authorization verification, which confirms the legitimacy of each transaction before proceeding:

Setting Up Payment Authorization Verification in Open Payment Framework

In addition, it's important to ensure accurate tracking of transactions. This is where the necessary PSP mapping comes into play, allowing you to capture payment identifiers and traceability:

Mapping PSP References in Open Payment Framework

4. Optimizing Notifications for Reliable Transactions

With the authorization and reference mapping established, the next step is to set up notifications to maintain transparency and responsiveness in the transaction process. Begin by configuring webhooks to receive real-time updates on payment events:

Configuring Notifications in Open Payment Framework

Building on that, please delve into additional notification mappings, handling custom fields such as card expiry dates and customer order links, to enhance tracking accuracy:

Configuring Additional Notification Mappings in Open Payment Framework

Last but not least, to secure the notification process, you''ll need to set up notification authentication with Stripe's HMAC signatures, safeguarding your payment data:

Configuring Notification Authentication in Open Payment Framework

5. Building Dynamic and Secure Payment Configurations

Before proceeding to the capture configuration, it's important to understand that effective management of dynamic data in OPF is achieved through variables, which allow for flexible and secure configurations:

Managing Variables in Open Payment Framework for SAP Commerce Cloud

Next, we will focus on capture settings, guiding you through the API call configurations necessary to finalize payments via Stripe's Payment Intent, ensuring a seamless transition from authorization to capture:

Configuring Capture Settings in Open Payment Framework

6. Handling Refunds and Reversals

A robust payment system needs to support refunds and reversals. You will learn how to map refund requests for seamless customer service:

Mapping a Refund Request in Open Payment Framework

Once the setup is complete, you'll see how to test payment authorization, capture, and refund processes to ensure full-cycle transaction handling:

Testing Payment Authorization, Capture and Refund in Open Payment Framework

In addition, you'll learn to map and test authorization reversals, crucial for handling order cancellations and funds releases:

Mapping a Payment Authorization Reversal in Open Payment Framework

7. Advanced Payment Management: Reauthorization & API Enhancements

For ongoing transactions, you should also learn how to configure reauthorization, allowing for future payments on the same session:

Configuring Reauthorization in Open Payment Framework

And you'd learn how to test the reauthorization configuration to ensure it functions correctly within your environment:

Testing Reauthorization in Open Payment Framework for SAP Commerce Cloud

To extend the API capabilities, you can enhance the payment workflows by integrating adjacent API calls with custom fields, such as attaching customer data to checkout sessions for more personalized and efficient processes:

Using Adjacent API Calls with Custom Fields in Open Payment Framework in SAP Commerce Cloud

Should issues arise, you'll find guidance in resolving reauthorization problems, ensuring minimal disruption:

Resolving Reauthorization Issues in Open Payment Framework for SAP Commerce Cloud

And when necessary, manually adjust transaction statuses to maintain accurate records:

Manually Adjusting Transaction Statuses in Open Payment Framework for SAP Commerce Cloud

8. Broaden Payment Options

Finally, you can expand your payment options by configuring additional payment methods like PayPal and Link, providing your customers more flexibility at checkout:

Configuring Alternative Payment Methods in Open Payment Framework for SAP Commerce Cloud

Conclusion

This concludes the quick overview of each video in the video series:

Integrating Payment Services into SAP Commerce Cloud with Open Payment Framework

(You can also access the playlist directly to watch the videos one by one.)

This series serves as your comprehensive resource for mastering payment integration in SAP Commerce Cloud. Follow the step-by-step instructions to enable your business with reliable, flexible, and secure payment solutions.

Happy learning!

entry.title: Re: Implementation of a taxable entity across system boun...
entry.content:
Hello Janina,

Thank you very much for your question!

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) is helpful?

Implementation of DRC in Hybrid SAP Environments

Licensing Models

The licensing for Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) in a hybrid setup involving both public and private cloud systems can vary. Typically, licensing may be based on the number of documents processed, such as blocks of 10,000 invoices, rather than the number of company codes or users. It is advisable to consult with your SAP sales representative to get precise details tailored to your specific setup.

Technical Functionality

DRC is designed to handle complex scenarios, including the integration of company codes from different SAP systems. However, the automatic merging of company codes for a taxable entity across public and private clouds might require additional configuration or middleware solutions. While DRC can facilitate data processing and reporting, manual steps like using the FOTV app might still be necessary depending on the specific requirements and setup.

Lobster Integration

Integrating Lobster as middleware between public cloud, private cloud, and DRC is feasible, but it requires careful planning. Lobster can be used to map interfaces and facilitate data transfer between systems. Ensure that Lobster is configured to handle the data formats and communication protocols required by DRC.

Requirements for DRC Processing

To process data from the public cloud system using DRC, ensure that the necessary communication arrangements and data mappings are in place. This includes setting up the correct integration flows and ensuring that the data is compliant with the requirements of the DRC component for VAT returns in Germany (FI-LOC-VAT-DE).

Additional Considerations

While there is a separate DRC scenario for processing external data sources for electronic invoicing, reporting might not have the same flexibility. It is crucial to explore all available options and consult with SAP experts to find the best solution for your specific needs.

[1] Tips to assess and plan global e-invoicing solution implementation based on SAP Document and Report Compliance

entry.title: Re: SAP Business One
entry.content:
I agree with Johan, it‚Äôs important to understand that B1 and S/4 are fundamentally different solutions. 

B1 is typically suited to smaller organisations, with 'lighter' licensing, less add-ons and often deployed on-premise.

S/4 is designed for larger, complex organisations. It has a wider range of functionality, extensive datasets, modern interface (Fiori) and a range of deployment options with additional licensing/complexity.

Are you working within a specific vertical in B1? Or are you working as a generalist SAP functional support?

entry.title: IDOCs are Still Safe for SAP S/4HANA - SAP Clean Core Extensibility Level B
entry.content:
Intro 

IDOCs are safe to use in SAP S/4HANA programs‚Äîand if anyone tells you otherwise, point them to this blog to learn more. IDOCs are now officially part of SAP Clean Core Extensibility! That‚Äôs the big news from updated SAP Guidelines (OSS Note 3578329 ‚Äì Frameworks, Technologies and Development Patterns in Context of Clean Core Extensibility).

This ends the myth that IDOCs are ‚Äúdead.‚Äù They are not. They‚Äôre preserved as SAP Clean Core Level B Extensibility, which means your existing IDOC investments are safe. Let‚Äôs explore four perspectives‚Äîintegration, monitoring and error handling, performance, and testing‚Äîto see where APIs are recommended first, and where IDOCs still bring value.

1. Integration Perspective

SAP‚Äôs recommendation for new development in S/4HANA is clear: use modern integration technologies such as APIs, events, or OData services. They are the strategic direction and best fit for greenfield or transformation projects. That said, not all projects require reinvention. If your business processes remain largely the same as in ECC, and the goal is to reduce cost and risk, IDOCs can still be used. They are not prohibited, and as long as an IDOC type is not listed as deprecated in the SAP Simplification List, it is safe:
https://help.sap.com/docs/btc/lean-sdt-best-practices/sap-s-4hana-simplification-analysis?locale=en-US Because IDOCs are now Clean Core Level B Extensibility, continuing with them is fully supported in SAP S/4HANA on-premise and SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud. They offer a pragmatic path to de-risk projects and leverage existing know-how.‚ÄÉ

2. Monitoring and Error Handling Perspective

For new interfaces, SAP recommends using AIF (Application Interface Framework) to handle monitoring, error management, and business validations. AIF provides a powerful, unified monitoring layer, and in many cases it comes license-free (for standard SAP interfaces delivered in namespaces like /SDSLS or /LEEDI, or in CFIN, Document Compliance, or S/4HANA Public Cloud). Where APIs are deployed, AIF bridges the gap between technical payloads and business-friendly monitoring.

IDOCs still have a strong card here: their monitoring capabilities are mature, well-known, and integrated into standard SAP transactions. Functional users know how to work with WE02, BD87, and standard reprocessing flows. This means less training, less overhead, and faster resolution in day-to-day operations.

In other words: AIF is recommended, but IDOCs deliver proven stability in monitoring and error handling.

3. Performance Perspective

APIs are the recommended way forward, but they come with a structural tradeoff: their payloads are larger and typically handle transactions individually. This makes them more verbose and sometimes less efficient for high-volume use cases. IDOCs, in contrast, have long supported bundling, batching, and parallel processing at scale. They‚Äôve been the backbone of high-volume EDI and SAP-to-SAP integrations for decades, and their ability to handle millions of documents daily is field-proven. So while APIs are the strategic choice for new designs, IDOCs remain a safe performance option for scenarios with heavy data throughput.

4. Testing Perspective

Testing support for APIs exists (for example, with SXI_MONITOR), but it is more technical and often requires additional training for functional teams. For IDOCs, simulation and reprocessing are familiar to almost every SAP functional consultant. Tools like WE19 and BD87 make IDOC testing and troubleshooting accessible, reducing dependency on specialist skills.

For projects that need to standardize and automate testing across both APIs and IDOCs, solutions like Int4 Suite provide simulation and test automation capabilities that unify all SAP integration scenarios. You can learn more on how to test and simulate SAP integrations in this SAP learning Course: Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization So while APIs are recommended for new developments, IDOCs still offer ease of testing and proven tooling, especially in brownfield projects.

Conclusion

The strategic path forward in SAP S/4HANA is built on APIs, events, and frameworks like AIF. That‚Äôs the official recommendation, and it should guide greenfield and transformation projects. But IDOCs are far from obsolete. They are officially part of Clean Core extensibility, safe to use in both on-premise and private cloud, and carry unique advantages in performance, monitoring, and ease of testing. That makes them not only supported, but still a pragmatic and safe choice when the situation calls for stability, cost reduction, and risk mitigation.

entry.title: FIORI APP extensibility
entry.content:
I need to extend a standard Fiori application with a custom field. Normally, the recommended approach would be to use the Custom Fields and Logic app, which automatically creates a new field (with the ZZ1_ prefix) in the relevant table and exposes it to Fiori.

However, in my case, the situation is different:

The customer has already added a custom field ZCLASS in table MARD using an append structure and this field is already in use across multiple forms, reports (so it‚Äôs business critical)

If I use the Custom Fields and Logic app now, it will create a new field ZZ1_CLASS in MARD, which would lead to redundant fields for the same purpose.

My question is what is the correct approach to resolve this issue?

Thank you In advance

entry.title: Re: Requirement: WebI Waterfall Report ‚Äì GL Account Causing Multivalue and Export Issues
entry.content:
Hi,
1. To avoid #MULTIVALUE, if you're sure that results are correct after that, you can add an aggregation operator such as SUM, MIN, MAX where detailed dimension object is not included in block or line.

2. For Excel export, when the are too many lines, you sometimes get an error about max character limit exceeded.
    Resolution :

  1. In the CMC, go to Servers > Servers list > Properties of your WebIntelligenceProcessingServer servers
  2. Under the "Web Intelligence Common Services" section, increase the parameters below.
    Maximum Character Stream Size (MB)
    Binary Stream Maximum Size (MB)
    Most of the time, 500MB for the Maximum Character Stream Size and 100MB for the Binary Stream Maximum Size is enough. If needed you can set an higher value but you will not be able to enter more than 4000.
  3. Restart the updated servers
Hope this helps.
Beno√Æt

entry.title: Re: FIORI APP extensibility
entry.content:
Hi Lxbel,

Since the field already exists in MARD via an append structure, using the Custom Fields and Logic app will indeed generate a second field with a ZZ1_ prefix. To avoid redundant fields, a common approach is to bind the existing append field into your Fiori app directly instead of creating a new one through CFL.

I recommend that you try to create an extension CDS view that underlies the standard Fiori app, and include the existing ZCLASS field. This lets you expose that field to the UI without creating a duplicate.

Hope that helps point you in the right direction.
Regards,
Sudheer.

entry.title: Custom Analytical Queries - SAP CLOUD ERP Public Edition ( SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud )
entry.content:
Definition :  The Custom Analytical Queries app is a tool used for reporting and analysis.

This tool transforms and organizes raw data delivered from business documents into a meaningful grid. It abstracts the process of writing structured queries so that you don‚Äôt have to understand the query language or the technical details.

Custom Analytical Queries provides the fields required to design a query. You select the required fields and set filters for your query. You can add restricted measures, calculated measures, and preview the query results. The various options in Custom Analytical Queries and the task that you can perform using the options are as follows:

  • Search: Use to search an existing query.

  • New: Use to create a query.

  • Copy: Use to create queries from predefined SAP queries or from packages that you do not have permissions.

  • Adding Dimensions and Measures from the Data Source: Use to add a field from a data source to define a query or to remove a field from the query.

( Definition referred From :  Custom Analytical Queries - SAP Doc )

In my words , Custom analytical queries are a tool for dynamic representation of data in rows and columns which provide meaningful insights , business intelligence and summarization of data in a higher to lower drilldown model with aggregations and segregations .

( Literally I'm too bad in defining things in my own words )

You can consider the Custom analytical queries as a Key User extensible approach , but there are few scenarios where we might need the support of Developer extensions to meet our requirements .  Which will be explained below in the following portions . 

where to find the custom analytical queries ? 

Once you are in your Public cloud Launchpad , use the search bar  .

Or use the Left hamburger menu and scroll down till you find the Analytics  Section .

Once you click the Analytics  Section , You can find the Tile under the Query Design part .

How to Create an Analytical Query ? 

Navigate inside the tile , you can see the list of existing custom analytical queries and the  create button  .

SAP has already provided us some  analytical queries and all the released queries will be available here , we can use the existing ones as well as create our own . 

Now click on the create button and following pop up will come .

You can give your Analytical query name and choose the Data source you need and click on OK . 

click on the Data Source search help and you can see all your available data sources .

 

 after choosing the data source of you need you can continue with the field selection , setting the Dimensions ,setting  Measures , setting the filters , calculations etc ...

Before moving to the next segment or part of adjusting and setting query for our use , let me give you an idea about the data sources used in the Analytical queries or what are these data sources ? 

The data sources shown here are of 3 types mainly : 

1. SAP created and Released Analytical Queries and Cube

2. Custom Analytical Cube created using the Custom CDS view APP .

  

3. Custom CDS views Created Using Developer extensibility and the C1 contract set for Use in key user apps . There are few other things to be careful as well , you can use the sample code added below for reference .

Code Snippet for one of the Custom analytical cube created via eclipse :

 @AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZI_FINSTATKEYFI'
@VDM.viewType: #COMPOSITE
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #CHECK
@EndUserText.label: 'Statistical Keyfigures per period'
@ObjectModel.representativeKey: 'StatisticalKeyFigureItem'
@ObjectModel.usageType.sizeCategory: #XXL
@ObjectModel.usageType.dataClass:  #MIXED
@ObjectModel.usageType.serviceQuality: #D
@Analytics: { dataCategory: #CUBE }
@Analytics.internalName: #LOCAL 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@Metadata.allowExtensions:true

@ObjectModel.modelingPattern: #ANALYTICAL_CUBE
@ObjectModel.supportedCapabilities: [#ANALYTICAL_PROVIDER, 
                                     #CDS_MODELING_DATA_SOURCE,
                                     #SQL_DATA_SOURCE]
                                     
define view  ZI_FINSTAT2
  as select from I_FinStatisticalKeyFigureItem

  
{
       @Consumption.filter: {selectionType: #SINGLE, multipleSelections: false, mandatory: true}
       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_Ledger'
  key  Ledger,


       @Consumption.filter: {selectionType: #SINGLE, multipleSelections: false, mandatory: true}
       //@Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{ entity: { name: 'I_LedgerCompanyCodeVH' , element: 'CompanyCode' },
       //                                     additionalBinding: [ { localElement: 'Ledger' , element: 'Ledger' } ]
       //                                  }]
       //@Consumption.valueHelp: '_LedgerCompanyCodeVH'
       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_CompanyCode'
  key  CompanyCode,

       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_StatisticalKeyFigure'
  key  StatisticalKeyFigure,

       ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
       // Attention !!!
       // The following field is the LedgerFiscalYear (depends on ledger + company code)
       // Unfortunately we have called it FiscalYear (because the semantic seems to be clear)
       // Because of compatibility reasons we can not change it anymore
       //
       // This view has no FiscalYear (depends on company code)
       //
       // if you use this view in your views on top please write:  FiscalYear as LedgerFiscalYear
       // then you can make a join or union with the field from ACDOCA: LedgerFiscalYear (please ignore in this case the FiscalYear from ACDOCA)
       /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_FiscalYear'
  key  FiscalYear,

       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_FiscalPeriod'
  key  FiscalPeriod,

  key  StatisticalKeyFigureItem,


       FiscalYearPeriod,

       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_FiscalYearVariant'
       FiscalYearVariant,

       IsSpecialPeriod,


       //@ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_StatisticalKeyFigureCat'
       StatisticalKeyFigureCategory,

       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_UnitOfMeasure'
       StatisticalKeyFigQtyUnit,


       @Aggregation.default: #SUM
       @Semantics: { quantity : {unitOfMeasure: 'StatisticalKeyFigQtyUnit'} }
       StstclKeyFigIntmdPlanSumQty,



       GLRecordType,

       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_PlanningCategory'
       PlanningCategory,

       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_CostCenter'
       CostCenter,

       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_ProfitCenter'
       ProfitCenter,

       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_FunctionalArea'
       FunctionalArea,

       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_BusinessArea'
       BusinessArea,

       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_ControllingArea'
       ControllingArea,

       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_Segment'
       Segment,

       ControllingBusTransacType,

       AccountAssignmentType,



       ControllingObject,


       ControllingObjectClass,

       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_Order'
       OrderID,

       OrderCategory,

       @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'StatisticalKeyFigQtyUnit'
       @AnalyticsDetails: {
               exceptionAggregationSteps: [{ exceptionAggregationBehavior : #AVG, //LAST
                                             exceptionAggregationElements: ['FiscalPeriod']
                                          }]
           }
       @AnalyticsDetails.query.formula : 'StstclKeyFigIntmdActlFixedQty'
       @EndUserText.label: 'Fixed Quantity'
      
       cast(1 as abap.quan(15,3) )                        as Fixed_Quantity,
       @Consumption.hidden: true
       //@AnalyticsDetails.query.hidden: true  //  ==> is available but hidden at start of app
       @AnalyticsDetails.query.axis: #COLUMNS
       //@EndUserText.label: 'StatisticalKeyFigSumQty'
       //@DefaultAggregation: #FORMULA
       //@Semantics: { quantity : {unitOfMeasure: 'StatisticalKeyFigQtyUnit'} }
       @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'StatisticalKeyFigQtyUnit'
       @AnalyticsDetails: {
               exceptionAggregationSteps: [{ exceptionAggregationBehavior : #SUM,
                                             exceptionAggregationElements: ['FiscalPeriod']
                                          }]
           }
       @AnalyticsDetails.query.formula : 'StstclKeyFigIntmdActlSumQty'
       @EndUserText.label: 'Sum Quantity'
       //cast( cast(1 as abap.quan(15,3)) as fis_ui_sum_smexxx ) as StatisticalKeyFigSumQty,
       cast(1 as abap.quan(15,3) )                        as Sum_Quantity,
       @AnalyticsDetails.query.axis: #COLUMNS
       //@EndUserText.label: 'StatisticalKeyFigSumQty'
       //@DefaultAggregation: #FORMULA
       //@Semantics: { quantity : {unitOfMeasure: 'StatisticalKeyFigQtyUnit'} }
       @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'StatisticalKeyFigQtyUnit'
       @AnalyticsDetails.query.formula : 'StstclKeyFigIntmdActlSumQty'
       @EndUserText.label: 'Quantity'
       //cast( cast(1 as abap.quan(15,3)) as fis_ui_smexxx ) as StatisticalKeyFigureQuantity,
       cast(1 as abap.quan(15,3) )                        as Quantity,
     

       GrantID,

       //@ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_BudgetPeriod'
       BudgetPeriod,

       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_SalesDocument'
       SalesOrder,

       @ObjectModel.foreignKey.association: '_SalesDocumentItem'
       SalesOrderItem,

       CostCtrActivityType,

       ServiceDocumentType,

       ServiceDocument,

       ServiceDocumentItem,


       _ControllingArea,
       _Ledger,
       _CompanyCode,
       _LedgerCompanyCodeVH,
       _CostCenter,
       _ProfitCenter,
       _StatisticalKeyFigure,
       _StatisticalKeyFigureCat,
       _FiscalYear,
       _FiscalPeriod,
       _FiscalYearVariant,
       _UnitOfMeasure,
       _Segment,
       _FunctionalArea,
       _BusinessArea,
       _Order,
       _SalesDocument,
       _SalesDocumentItem,
       _ControllingObject,
       _BudgetPeriod,
       _PlanningCategory


}

Now lets Fall back to our scenario , I am creating an Analytical query with the name Analytical_Q2 and data source  I_ACCOUNTINGDOCUMENTJOURNAL , one of SAP released / Standard CDS views.

and you will be on the next screen after clicking OK .

You will be in the first tab General , 

in the General tab under properties , you can :

  • add your Label 
  •  Name and Data source will be displayed 
  • Set the Zero suppression

Under the Additional Properties , you can :

  •  Processing effort for the query , Low / Medium / High 
  • Set Run Time extensibility 

On the top right corner you can see your status of the Query (Draft / Saved / published )

On the bottom right you can see buttons for , Saving Draft / Publishing / Previewing 

 

Moving to the Next Tab  Field selection : 

You can see all your fields available in the Data source here . Check the selection check box for fields you will be needing in the query . 

After selecting the check box you can see that most of the fields fell in to the Free axis position but some of them have automatically fallen to the Measure category . Mostly the fields with amount , quantity or marked as measure in the data source fall to this category. 

If you look closely to the field list , you can see the type of field . 

  • if a field is having  symbol , this is a dimension and could be placed in the ROW / Column axis of the report / Query.
  • if a field is having  symbol , this is a measure and could be placed in the COLUMN axis of the report / Query.
  • if a field is having  symbol , this is a date field and could be placed in ROW / Column axis of the report / Query.

In data analysis, dimensions are qualitative, descriptive fields (like names, dates, or categories) that provide context and "slice" data, answering "who," "what," "when," and "where". Measures are quantitative, numerical fields (like sales, quantities, or profits) that you calculate or aggregate to answer "how much" or "how many". The core difference is that dimensions provide the descriptive context, while measures provide the numerical values to analyze within that context. 

Dimensions
Purpose: To provide context, segment, and describe data.
Data Type: Qualitative, categorical, or descriptive data.
Examples:
Product names, customer IDs, region, date.
Information like "who," "what," "where," and "when".
Measures
Purpose: To be calculated and aggregated, such as sums or averages, to provide quantifiable insights. 
Data Type: Quantitative, numerical, and measurable data. 
Examples: 
Sales, profit, quantity, price, and temperature. 
Information that answers "how much" or "how many". 
 
Moving to the Next Tab Display :
Now you can move the fields to your desired axis , Row / Column. To do that you can either select the field and use the up , down button in the table to move the fields and place it in order . Or you can also use the Axis field in the options area and place the field in different Axis.
I have adjusted the axis in the following order: 
Now lets focus the main table with fields from left ,
  • you will see Remove column with x button to remove the field from the selection.
  • Filter column to set the Filed as a filter ( We will look at the Filter in the next section or tab).
  • Display column to hide / show the field in output. 
  • Name , label and Type as seen earlier and also a row wise hierarchy  separator to show the fields category or placement.
 
Now lets Save our Query and have a Preview :
We will consider this preview for comparing with changes we are going to next.
Now lets select a field in the row category and look at the available properties (Right Pane) . 

 

  • Use the Override Label to change the default Label :
  • Display option to set field visible .
  • Display result Option to enable Total / Grand total row based on this field .
  • Dimension format to display either the Key  / text / Key and text / text and Key  value of the Field , Applicable in case of fields with Key and value pair , eg : Country , currency , company code etc 
  • Sorting to set the sorting for the Field , Ascending / descending . 
  • Axis is to place the field at desired axis (Row / Column).
  • Include Unbooked data option to show values with this field as empty but others having data .
 
Now lets look at a Measure and its Properties :
  • Use the Override Label to change the default Label :
  • Display option to set field visible .
  • Decimals option to define the number of decimal places needed.
  • Scaling option to set the level of scaling .
  • Reverse sign to reverse the sign of value .
  • Use  the hierarchy  Part to set the Hierarchy of the field if needed.
  • Collapsed to set the view to collapsed .
  • Enable hierarchy to enable hierarchy , Collapsed will only work if hierarchy is set . 
  • Parent option to set the parent node of the current field in the hierarchy.
 
Now after making some changes let me show the preview again :
Moving to the Next Tab Filters :
 
Here lets select a Row / Dimension and set the Filter values , Only dimensions are allowed as filters .
 
  • You can set No filter for a field , which will be default .
  • Fixed Filter with values to
    • include and exclude.
  • User Input Values Filter with
    • selection type  Single / Interval
    • Multiple selection
    • Mandatory Option
    • Variable sequence
    • Default value
  • Derivation Functions with 
    • Lookup entity (Search help )
    • Hidden 
    • Mandatory

Now after making some changes let me show the preview again :

 

Now we have covered almost all the options in all the tabs , but we haven't explored the ADD button in the Display tab . 

This option lets you add :

  • Add Restricted Measure
  • Add Calculated Measure
  • Add Converted Measure
  • Add Counter
  • Add User Input Filter
  • Add Characteristic Structure Element
     
     
     
    I have also skipped the publishing process and adding the custom analytical query as a tile in this tile , I will try to write all the missing parts in the part 2 blog üòÅ .
     
     
    NB : This Blog is created based on my knowledge , experiments and experiences . If you have found any misleading information in the blog , please correct me in the comments . Happy Learning üòä .

entry.title: From My Inbox to SAP Task Center: A Customer‚Äôs Journey to Unified Task Management
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs enterprise landscape, employees often navigate multiple systems to complete everyday approvals - such as leave requests in SAP SuccessFactors, invoices in SAP Ariba, purchase orders in SAP S/4HANA, or workflows in SAP Build Process Automation.

For many organizations, SAP Fiori My Inbox has served as the go-to solution for managing workflow tasks. However, with the adoption of more SAP Cloud solutions, customers are looking for a central, scalable, and modern task hub that goes beyond the capabilities of My Inbox.

This is where SAP Task Center comes into play. And with the help of the official Transition Guide, customers can make this shift with confidence.

Why the Transition Guide Matters

One of our customers, a global manufacturing company, recently began their journey from My Inbox to SAP Task Center. For their IT team, the Transition Guide was an essential resource that addressed the most critical questions:

  • Feature Clarity: A direct comparison of My Inbox and SAP Task Center capabilities helped them map existing functionality to the new experience.
  • Migration Planning: Clear guidance on prerequisites, dependencies, and planning considerations made it easy to build a structured rollout plan.
  • Implementation Steps: Detailed instructions on setup, authentication, and connector configuration ensured the transition was straightforward and predictable.

‚ÄúThe guide made it feel less like a migration project and more like a natural upgrade path.‚Äù ‚Äî IT Manager, Customer Project

Benefits of Moving to SAP Task Center

After adopting SAP Task Center, the customer quickly began to see measurable benefits:

  • Unified Inbox: All approvals and workflow items from multiple systems consolidated into a single, central inbox.
  • Time Savings: Reduced time spent switching between different applications for task approvals.
  • Resilience: Cached task storage ensured availability even if backend systems were temporarily unreachable.
  • Flexibility: Multiple service plan options allowed fine-tuning of task federation.
  • Mobile Enablement: Seamless integration with SAP Mobile Start provided executives with approvals on the go.

The result: higher task completion rates, reduced approval bottlenecks, and improved employee experience.

A Unified Future for Task Management

For organizations still relying on My Inbox, the transition to SAP Task Center is more than a technical migration‚Äîit‚Äôs a strategic opportunity to streamline work, empower employees, and prepare for future growth.

The Transition Guide ensures that this move is achievable and well-supported, regardless of IT landscape complexity.

How to Get Started

Read the official Transition Guide to SAP Task Center
Explore SAP Task Center in SAP Discovery Center
Join the conversation in the SAP Community for Task Center

SAP Task Center represents the next generation of task management for SAP landscapes‚Äîbringing together approvals, workflows, and actions from multiple solutions into one unified experience.

With the Transition Guide, customers can move forward with clarity, confidence, and a proven roadmap for success.

entry.title: Generative AI use cases for ecommerce implementations
entry.content:
Introduction

The crucial step which converts a browse to a buy in ecommerce applications is the product search. A user browses an ecommerce site for an interested product using a keyword or a descriptive search, finds the relevant product and continues to place an order for the same. Any difficulty in finding the desired product leads to an unpleasant user experience, leading to customer support calls or leaving of the site without a purchase. 

The advent of Generative AI has revolutionized the ecommerce domain like many other domains. Generative AI is the ability of Large Language Models (LLMs / SLMs) to create contextual and personalized content. Generative AI, powered by Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG), has seen massive impact in building applications and chatbots that can utilize enterprise data to power the LLM generations. Personalization and Hyper-personalization help building an elevated customer experience. The Gen AI Agents are driven by instruction or prompt templates that can capture the user questions and related parameters to generate a response referring to the context provided to the LLM

Main Portion

The power of Generative AI can weaponize ecommerce applications in enhancing the user purchase experience in multiple ways. There are two such use cases which are most common in global purchasing experiences. 

One of the use cases is product search, where almost all ecommerce applications provide a search option to accept user's input and show relevant product search results for the user to choose from. Gen AI Powered Product Search supporting natural intent based & personalized conversational search, providing the ability to search based on descriptive content and not only the attribute data model, short searches and abbreviations the search queries, accept typos and grammatical errors to not impact search results. The below features would be possible

  • Search using natural language and free flowing text-based interaction
  • Independent of underlying field mappings, preset rules and domain intricacies
  • Personalized Search Experience along with Recommendations

Second use case is a purchase assistant chatbot. Ecommerce websites usually provide a chat support to help the users through a live customer support agent integrating with a third-party solution or an automated chatbot which can support with limited set of responses while sharing a contact number for further support. With Gen AI powered purchase assistant chatbot, the users can be given a personalized purchasing experience by recommending products based on user prompts combined with user's previous purchase history. This would help user with guidance for quickly placing the desired order. The below would be possible features

  • User can ask questions from a generic context through prompts
  • User can make purchases based upon product facets
  • User can make purchases based upon keyword driven searches

The Generative AI solutions would in summary empower an ecommerce application with

  • Semantic & Intent based searches‚Äã and chat interfaces
  • Relevance ranking of results‚Äã
  • Auto spell corrections
  • Personalized suggestions based on user‚Äôs past search history‚Äã
  • Collaborative filtering to recommend items bought by similar users
  • Recommend next best products to be ordered referring to the order history of purchases

Conclusion

While these solutions can be custom built as per the ecommerce applications using various available technologies like Open AI GPT models, Langchain, Vector DB etc., the ecommerce platforms are also coming up with their own GEN AI tool kits which can be integrated. An example would be SAP CX AI Tooklit by SAP Commerce Cloud.

As Generative AI opens a new era in ecommerce transforming selling, marketing and customer experiences, the existing and new ecommerce applications would have a competitive advantage by adapting the Gen AI solutions for identified relevant use cases and staying ahead in the digital ecommerce landscape.

entry.title: ABAP Cloud Number Ranges: The¬†ABAP RAP COMMIT WORK¬†Conflict and the Simple Fix
entry.content:
Introduction

Many business applications require unique numbers, for example, to complete the keys of data records. In order to get numbers from an interval, a number range object must be defined which can contain different properties. Standard Number ranges are typically maintained via customizing in each system (Test and Production). However, the process for custom Number Range Objects in the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is different.

These custom objects must be created in the development environment, configured in the customizing client, and then transported through the landscape. This blog outlines that end-to-end process, including a frustrating short dump I encountered and the surprisingly simple configuration change that solved it.

Part 1: The Developer's Task - Defining the Blueprint in ADT

Unlike the on-premises world, the process for a custom number range begins in the developer's toolkit: ABAP Development Tools (ADT). Here, you create the definition or the blueprint of your number range object.

  1. In your ABAP package, right-click and choose New -> Other ABAP Repository Object.
  2. Search for "Number Range Object", give it a name and a description.
  3. Assign it to a Workbench Transport.
  4. In the object editor, the most important property is the Number Length Domain. It‚Äôs a best practice to create a custom domain for this to define the length and type. For my ZPO_RUN_ID, I used a domain of type NUMC(10).
  5. Save and activate the object.

The system now knows what a ZPO_RUN_ID is, but it has no actual number intervals defined.

Part 2: The Customizer's Task - Setting Intervals in Fiori

This is where we move to the Fiori Launchpad, specifically in the Customizing Client.

  1. Log in to your Customizing client and open the "Manage Number Range Intervals" Fiori app.
  2. Search for your newly created object, ZPO_RUN_ID.
  3. Navigate to the "Number Ranges" tab and click "Create". Here you'll define your interval, for example, 01 with its lower and upper limits.

Part 3: The Transport

The system needs a Customizing Transport to record this change.

  1. In a new tab, open the "Export Customizing Transports" Fiori app.

  1. Create a new "Customizing Request" and give it a description. It's a good practice to set this as your "Default" request using the "Change Category" button.

  1. Go back to the Number Range app and save your interval again. This time, it will find your open request and save the change successfully.

Now you have two transports: the Workbench TR from ADT with the object definition, and the Customizing TR from Fiori with the interval data. The Workbench TR should be a prerequisite for the Customizing TR when you import them.

Part 4: The Payoff - Using the Number Range in RAP

With everything configured, it was time to use it in my ABAP RAP application. The correct, released API is the class CL_NUMBERRANGE_RUNTIME.

I had two main options for assigning an ID based on the business requirement:

  • An early numbering determination, which runs before the save phase.
  • A determination on save, which runs during the final save transaction.

I initially chose early numbering determination. My earlynumbering_create method was clean and used the correct class.

METHOD earlynumbering_create.

    DATA: latest_num   TYPE cl_numberrange_runtime=>nr_number.

    DATA(All_entities) = entities.
    DELETE All_entities WHERE  RunId IS NOT INITIAL.

    TRY.
        cl_numberrange_runtime=>number_get(
          EXPORTING
            nr_range_nr = '01'
            object      = 'ZPO_RUN_ID'
            quantity = CONV #( lines( all_entities ) )
          IMPORTING
            number      = latest_num
            returncode = DATA(code)
            returned_quantity = DATA(return_qty) ).

      CATCH cx_nr_object_not_found INTO DATA(lx_obj_not_found).
      CATCH cx_number_ranges INTO DATA(lx_ranges_error).

        LOOP AT All_entities INTO DATA(entity_line).

          APPEND VALUE #( %cid = entity_line-%cid
                          %key  = entity_line-%key ) TO failed-run.
          APPEND VALUE #( %cid = entity_line-%cid
                          %key = entity_line-%key
                          %msg = lx_ranges_error ) TO reported-run.
        ENDLOOP.
        EXIT.
    ENDTRY.

    DATA(curr_num) = latest_num - return_qty.

    LOOP AT All_entities INTO entity_line.
      curr_num = curr_num + 1 .
      APPEND VALUE #( %cid = entity_line-%cid
      RunUuid = curr_num ) TO mapped-run.

    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.

I ran the app, created an entry, clicked "Save," and was met with a short dump: ABAP Runtime error 'BEHAVIOR_ILLEGAL_STATEMENT'.

 

The "Aha!" Moment: The COMMIT WORK Conflict and the Simple Fix

My code was correct. The class was correct. The configuration was correct. So, what was wrong?

The problem was my number range was not buffered.

After a long debugging session, I discovered that when cl_numberrange_runtime is called for a non-buffered number range, it must perform an immediate database UPDATE and its own COMMIT WORK to guarantee the number is reserved. The RAP framework, in its strictly controlled Save phase, saw this independent COMMIT as a violation of its own transaction and triggered the dump to prevent data inconsistency.

The solution wasn't in my ABAP code at all. It was in the configuration.

Enabling buffering solves this transactional conflict. Here‚Äôs why:

  • With buffering, the class gets the next number from the application server's memory, not directly from the database.
  • Getting a number from memory requires no immediate database update and, crucially, no conflicting COMMIT WORK.

I edited the Properties of my ZPO_RUN_ID object and changed the Buffering type to "Main Memory Buffering" with a size of 10.

With that one configuration change, everything worked perfectly. My determination on save now executes without any issues.

Final Thoughts

In the ABAP Cloud, writing correct code is only half the battle. We also have to deeply understand and respect the strict transactional model of the RAP framework. A seemingly simple configuration choice, like buffering, can be the key to resolving what looks like a complex runtime error.

If you ever face an unexpected BEHAVIOR_ILLEGAL_STATEMENT dump, consider what your code might be doing that could be trying to interfere with the framework's unit of work.

entry.title: Re: I have a requirement where 2030 costs needs to be dis...
entry.content:
Hi @Pallavi_Dasgupta98 

If you want to distribute the same amount across the planning periods, the following data action script can be a solution.

Model - Version dimension

For each planning version, the planning period must be defined as a property.

  • 2025_Plan: Plan_Start=202601, Plan_End=202912
  • 2026_Plan: Plan_Start=202701, Plan_End=202912

      

Data Action Script (Advanced formulas)

//Date scope is set based on the Version Property Plan_Start & Plan_End
MEMBERSET [d/Date] = [d/Version].[p/Plan_Start] TO [d/Version].[p/Plan_End]

//Define Integer variable @No_Of_Plan_Month.
INTEGER @No_Of_Plan_Month

//Calculate how many months the planning period spans.
@No_Of_Plan_Month = DATEDIFF([d/Version].[p/Plan_Start], [d/Version].[p/Plan_End], "MONTH") + 1

//2030.Jan costs is distributed in planning years.
DATA([d/Account] = "Cost_01") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "Cost_01", [d/Date] = "203001") / @No_Of_Plan_Month

Source Data & Calculated result

  • Version: 2025_Plan
    • Planning Period: 202601 ~ 202912 (48 months)
    • Source value: 4,800(Date=203001, Account=Cost_01)

 

  • Version: 2026_Plan
    • Planning Period: 202701 ~ 202912 (36 months)
    • Source value: 7,200(Date=203001, Account=Cost_01)

 

I hope this is helpful to you, and if I have misunderstood anything, please feel free to reach out.

Moonjun

entry.title: Custom Report in Project System
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We are planning costs on the WBS using unit cost method. The planned costs on a WBS is sum of planned costs for various item categories, obtained using simple multiplication of price and quantity. The costs will be planned in different versions. My client requires a report that compares the price, quantity, value of each item category in different versions for a particular WBS element or for the whole project (but WBS element wise). I am trying to prepare the functional specification of the report for ABAP development. CONSIDER A SITUATION WHERE BUDGET IS NOT PLANNED. I started by passing the project definition in PSPHI table of PRPS table and passing the WBS element in POSID field of the same table. I obtained OBJNR from this. I then passed OBJNR in RPSCO table along with the version in VERSN and obtained the details on planned costs with WRTTP for planned values. I am now unable to understand the link between RPSCO and CKHS table. If I pass OBJNR directly in CKHS, I am able to obtain KALNR. This KALNR is further passed in CKIS table to get the item category wise detail, i.e., price, quantity and value corresponding to each item category. Can you please guide me to establish a link between RPSCO and CKHS table? This link is necessary to pull the version in. If budget is planned, I can directly see BPGE table for VERSN and obtain KALNR and then pass KALNR in CKIS table to obtain the details at the level of item category. Will this still be the solution in cases of no budgets? Thanks
